PO every six (6) hours as needed for pain.

Home

Secondary diagnoses: 
- Osteoarthritis
- Fibromyalgia
- Anxiety
- Depression
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Brown,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent 
hospitalization at Bayshore Community Healthcare System.  You were 
admitted for abdominal pain that was not relieved by pain 
medications.  Imaging studies did not show any signs of obstruction 
or other serious issues.  We recommend that you follow up with 
your primary physician and a gastroenterologist to further work 
up your symptoms.

Please note the following changes to your home medications: 
START oxycodone-acetaminophen as needed for pain

Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
experience any of the following:

*Severe abdominal pain that is not improving within 24 hours.*
*Blood in stool, urine, or vomit.*
*Fevers >101.5 degrees*
*Chills
*Severe nausea and/or vomiting
*Difficulty breathing
*Any other symptoms that are concerning to you.

Thank you for allowing us to be a part of your care!

Sincerely,
Your Bayshore Community Healthcare System Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Please schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel in 1-2 weeks to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed. During this visit, we will also discuss any further testing or referrals that may be necessary based on your ongoing symptoms. If you experience worsening of symptoms or have concerns before then, please contact our office to schedule an urgent appointment. Thank you for entrusting us with your care!

Name:  Robert Welch                Unit No:   4449871

Date of Birth:  1949-10-30             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: Dr. Julianne Sloane

Discharge Medications:
1.  Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY  
2.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain, fever >100.4  
3.  Amphetamine-Dextroamphetamine (APC) 10 mg PO BID  
4.  Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY  
5.  Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM  
6.  Carbidopa-Levodopa (Rasagiline) 1 TAB PO TID  
7.  Citalopram 40 mg PO DAILY  
8.  Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 2 SPRY NU DAILY  
9.  Gabapentin 100 mg PO QAM  
10. Lidocaine Patch 1 PTCH TD Q8H:PRN back pain, radiculopathy 
11. Multivitamins W/minerals 1 TAB PO DAILY  
12. Omeprazole 20 mg PO BID  
13. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H  
14. Ranitidine HCl 150 mg PO BID  
15. Simvastatin 10 mg PO QPM  
16. Vitamin C 500 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS
- Acute on Chronic Subdural Hematoma

SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS
- Parkinson disease
- Hyperlipidemia
- Hypertension
- Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
- Depression
- Anxiety 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Welch,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization 
at West Ashley Regional Hospital.  You were admitted because of 
your headache and confusion, and we found that you had bleeding in 
the brain.  We took you to the operating room for surgery where 
we removed some of the fluid from around your brain.  After the 
surgery, your headache improved and you have been able to eat a 
normal diet.

We recommend that you follow-up with Dr. Julianne Sloane at the 
appointment listed below. 

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, tightness, or 
 squeezing.
*New or worsening cough or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
 medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within Torres hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse, changes location, or moves to your chest or back.

Please take your medications as directed. Do NOT drink alcohol, 
drive a motor vehicle, or operate machinery while taking any of 
these medications.  
*If you are prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin), have your blood 
levels checked regularly.
*Please do not stop taking your Dilantin until told to by Dr. Julianne Sloane.

General Instructions:
*Continue to ambulate several times per day and drink plenty of 
fluids.
*Avoid heavy lifting, straining, or excessive bending for one (1) 
week following surgery. You may resume all normal activities at 
that time.
*You may shower and wash your hair with a mild soap as soon as 
possible after surgery.
*Do not use any ointments or lotions on the incision until told to 
by Dr. Julianne Sloane.

Please call the office if you have any questions, concerns, or 
require further medical attention. It was a pleasure caring for 
you!

Sincerely,
Your West Ashley Regional Hospital Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Follow up with Dr. Julianne Sloane in 2 weeks to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed. Please schedule this appointment by calling our office at least 24 hours prior to ensure availability. If you experience any

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Brown,

You were admitted to the hospital because you had chest pain 
and abnormal EKG changes concerning for a heart attack.  You 
were found to have an occlusion in your coronary arteries.  A 
stent was placed and the occlusion opened.  You are being 
discharged home on medications to help prevent another 
heart attack.

Please continue taking all of your medications as directed.  
Please follow up with Dr. Julianne Marquez as scheduled below.

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospital stay.
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Julianne Marquez in 2 weeks for re-evaluation and further treatment planning, or sooner if you experience any worsening symptoms such as chest pain or shortness of breath. During this time, please continue to take all medications as prescribed and follow a heart-healthy diet. Schedule an appointment by calling our office at least one day prior to your visit date to confirm availability. If you have questions or concerns before your scheduled follow-up, feel free to reach out to our team for assistance. We look forward to supporting you in your recovery!

Name:  Kieran McCormick                   Unit No:   8448461
 
Admission Date:  2024-09-23              Discharge Date:   2024-10-06
 
Date of Birth:  1952-12-17             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Aspirin
 
Attending: Dr. Julianne Patel

Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO every six (6) hours.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
3.  Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4.  Oxycodone-Acetaminophen Evans mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5.  Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. McCormick,

You came to the hospital with left leg pain. You had an X-ray of 
your leg which showed you have a stress fracture in your tibia.

Please follow these instructions:

Take all medications as prescribed.
Do NOT take any NSAIDs such as Aspirin, Ibuprofen, or Motrin 
for two weeks after surgery. This can cause further bleeding at 
the site of the operation and delay healing. If you need to take 
an NSAID for pain control ask your doctor if it is okay first.
Limit your activities to those mentioned below in the activity 
section. These are general guidelines and may need to be adjusted 
according to how you are feeling on a particular day.
Take your pain medication as directed. If your pain is not 
getting better call the office. You can also take over the counter 
medications such as Tylenol or Motrin for minor discomfort if 
allowed by your doctor. 
You may shower and wash around your incision site but do NOT 
get the incision wet.
You may eat a regular diet.

If you have any questions or concerns that are not answered in this 
discharge packet, please call our office at Eastview Community Hospital.  
We will be happy to speak with you and answer any questions you may 
have. If you experience any of the following symptoms, please seek 
medical attention immediately by calling your doctor or going to 
the nearest emergency room.
Increased pain that is not controlled with pain medications
Increased swelling of your leg
Decreased sensation in your toes
Ability to feel objects being placed on foot
Temperature greater than 101.5 for 24 hours
Any other questions or concerns

It was a pleasure taking care of you at Eastview Community Hospital.
 
Followup Instructions:
Please return to see Dr. Julianne Patel in 2 weeks for a follow-up appointment to assess your progress and remove sutures as needed. During this time, if you experience any increased pain or swelling, please contact our office to schedule an emergency visit with Dr. Julianne Patel.

Name:  Kieran McCormick                     Unit No:   2451158

Service: PEDIATRICS

Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain/fever  
2.  Augmentin 875-125 mg PO BID  
3.  Senna 8.6 mg PO DAILY  
4.  Simethicone 40-80 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis:
Acute Sinusitis
Bronchiolitis

Secondary diagnoses:
Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)
Ear Infection 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. McCormick,

You were admitted to the pediatric hospital with difficulty breathing, ear pain and a cough. You had your blood drawn which showed that you had an infection (RSV). Your chest x-ray showed that your lungs were clear but your sinuses were infected. You were treated with antibiotics and your symptoms improved over time. On discharge, you are feeling better and breathing well without any difficulty.

Please take all of the medications as prescribed, complete your 
full course of antibiotics to prevent re-infection and follow-up 
with your primary care physician within the next week for a 
re-check of your blood work.
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Julianne Marquez in 7-10 days for a follow-up appointment to assess the effectiveness of treatment and make any necessary adjustments to your care plan. Please call our office at least 24 hours prior to your scheduled visit to confirm your appointment time. If you experience any worsening symptoms or concerns between now and then, do not hesitate to contact Dr. Julianne Marquez's office for immediate attention.

Home

Hypertension

Thyroid nodule

 
Discharge Condition:

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Slade,

You were admitted to the Neurosurgery service with left sided 
weakness. You underwent an MRI of your brain which showed a 
stroke in the right posterior cerebral artery (PCA). You had a 
repeat MRI 24 hours later that showed some improvement in the 
stroke.

We started you on aspirin, Plavix and Atrovastatin to prevent 
another stroke. We also started you on Levothyroxine for your 
hypothyroidism.

You were seen by Physical Therapy who felt that you would be 
able to go home with outpatient Physical therapy.

Please follow up with Neurology at the appointment below. If 
you are unable to keep this appointment, please call and cancel 
at least 24 hours prior to the scheduled time of your 
appointment.
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Marquez in 4-6 weeks to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed based on symptom resolution or improvement. If you experience any worsening of symptoms or have concerns before your scheduled appointment, do not hesitate to reach out to Dr. Julianne Marquez's office for immediate attention.

Name:  Avery Wellesley                Unit No:   8449468
 
Admission Date:  2024-10-03              Discharge Date:   2024-10-06
 
Date of Birth:  1984-05-11             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: Dr. Julianne Patel

Discharge Medications:
1.  Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY  
2.  Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY  
3.  Simvastatin 10 mg PO QPM  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Migraine headache

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Wellesley,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your admission to 
Fulton Community Hospital.  You were admitted with headache, 
nausea, vomiting, and visual disturbance.  Your symptoms were 
likely due to migraine headaches.  We started you on IV fluids 
and pain medication without improvement in your headache.  You 
were evaluated by neurology who felt that your headache was most 
consistent with a migraine headache.  We also performed an MRI of 
your brain which showed no evidence of stroke or other acute 
process.

We made the following changes to your medications:
- Started Aspirin 81mg daily
- Started Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg daily

Please continue to take all of your home medications as 
prescribed.  Please DO NOT restart any blood pressure or heart 
medications until you see your primary care doctor in the next 
few weeks.  We are not sure what dose is appropriate for you at 
this time.

Please follow up with neurology on an outpatient basis within 4 
weeks.  Please also schedule a follow-up appointment with your 
primary care physician within the next few weeks to discuss 
restarting some of your blood pressure and heart medications.

Thank you again for allowing us to participate in your care.
-Your Fletcher Community Hospital Team 
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Julianne Patel in 2 weeks for re-evaluation of migraine headache symptoms and to assess response to current treatment plan. If symptoms worsen or new concerns arise before then, please contact our office to schedule an urgent appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel.
